journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: An improved Yasutomi correlation for viscosity at high pressure

article-meta.aff: 1Center for High-Pressure Rheology, George W. Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
2CNRS INSA-Lyon, Université de Lyon, LaMCoS, Villeurbanne, France
3TOTAL, CReS, Chemin du Canal, Solaize, France

author-notes.corresp: Scott Bair, Center for High-Pressure Rheology, George W. Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0405, USA. Email: scott.bair@me.gatech.edu

abstract.p: The Yasutomi temperature–pressure–viscosity correlation is attractive for elastohydrodynamic lubrication analysis because it does not require an equation of state for the liquid. However, the original Yasutomi correlation suffers from the appearance of a zero in the function describing the pressure dependence of the relative free volume thermal expansivity. When the original correlation is employed, a liquid with a high inflection pressure lacks the inflection in the predicted pressure–viscosity behavior and a liquid with a low inflection pressure is predicted to have two inflections. A new function removes these concerns and provides improved precision without the need for an equation of state. The improved function gives a more faithful representation of viscosity at even low pressures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The field of elastohydrodynamic lubrication (EHL) has within a few years undergone a revolution. Using the viscosity measured in viscometers with sensible correlations, new EHL discoveries are being made through analysis before they are experimentally observed.1–3 Prior to this, the use of viscometers in EHL was considered controversial.4 Quantitative analyses require a description of at least the pressure dependence of viscosity and the study of thermal effects requires a temperature–pressure correlation. Also, the shear-dependent viscosity is often essential. These temperature–pressure correlations have employed either the Doolittle free-volume theory5 or the Ashurst–Hoover thermodynamic scaling with an appropriate scaling function.6 The latter have proven to be the most accurate. Both forms require that the equation of state be known or estimated for the particular liquid lubricant. For predicting film thickness in EHD contacts, the actual pressure–(temperature)–viscosity dependence at low pressure should be accurately described by the employed model. For understanding EHL friction, the pressure–viscosity response is important at pressures greater than the inflection pressure, pnfl, where the pressure fragility is manifested.7 The inflection pressure is the pressure for which ∂2lnμ/∂p2=0.

While an equation of state is required for a compressible solution to the EHL problem, these are not always available even when viscosities are. A correlation which does not require the equation of state was derived from the Doolittle free volume theory by Yasutomi and coworkers8 and is a pressure-modified version of the Williams–Landel–Ferry9 equation. For a complete derivation see Bair.10 The notion that the glass transition is an isoviscous state with low-shear viscosity equal to μg provides a reference state. This correlation may accurately describe the temperature and pressure, T and p , dependence of the low-shear viscosity, μ , over the temperature and pressure range of measured viscosities and, for some liquids, provide a sensible extrapolation for perhaps 300 MPa greater than the measurement pressure. It cannot, however, provide sensible extrapolations above the range of measured pressure for liquids with a low inflection pressure11,12 and may even lack an inflection for liquids with large inflection pressure. The Yasutomi model is (1)μ=μgexp [-2.303C1 (T-Tg )FC2+ (T-Tg )F ] where Tg (p ) is the glass transition temperature which varies with pressure as (2)Tg=Tg0+A1ln (1+A2p )

The dimensionless relative thermal expansivity of the free volume, F (p ), is given by an empirical expression from Breuer and Rehage13 for the total thermal expansivity of the liquid, assuming that the temperature dependences of the free volume and total volume change with pressure in the same way (3)F=1-B1ln (1+B2p ) When p= [exp (1/B1 )-1 ]/B2, then F (p )=0 and at this pressure all isotherms must converge at μ=μg. The calculated viscosity is decreasing with pressure near this pressure and, for pressures greater than this pressure, the calculated viscosity increases with temperature, which is not a sensible result.

This short communication introduces a new function for relative thermal expansivity of the free volume, F' (p ), which behaves in a manner similar to F (p ) at low pressure without vanishing at high pressure. It will be shown that the previous deficiencies at high pressure influence the accuracy at even the lowest pressures.

sec.title: New free volume expansivity function
sec.p: The obvious requirements for F' (p ) are that it should approximate F (p ) at low pressures and remain greater than zero for all reasonable positive pressures. A function with these properties is (4)F'= (1+b1p )b2

Equating the first three terms of the Taylor series about p=0 for F' (p ) and F (p ) gives an approximation for b1 and b2, which may be helpful in the regression of new parameters for application of equation (4) to data for which the original Yasutomi parameters are available. In that case, a regression may be initialized with (5)b1≈B2 (1-B1 )b2≈B11-B1

An example is made of squalane, a liquid with a large inflection pressure. Squalane has been used as a reference liquid for investigations in quantitative EHL14,15 and measured viscosities have been reported to 1.2 GPa and to 100 °C.14 Additional data at 150 °C are used here from the same measurement set. The parameters were found from a least squares regression of the measured data for both versions of the free volume expansivity (equations (2) to (4)). Results are listed in Table 1 along with standard deviation which was reduced from 8.0% to 5.8% by the new function. Table 1.
Parameters for the correlation using different functions for the relative free volume expansivity.
Material Squalane Nissan CVT fluid
Function F F′ F F′
μg (Pa·s) 1012 1012 107 107
Tg0 (°C) −112.9 −96.6 −68.6 −66.9
A1 (°C) 88.87 270.5 160.5 317.4
A2 (GPa−1) 1.243 0.2377 1.816 0.7704
C1 16.64 16.38 10.94 11.18
C2 (°C) 30.89 25.22 28.97 33.40
B1 0.1720 – 0.3024 –
B2 (GPa−1) 29.97 – 12.64 –
b1 (GPa−1) – 9.83 – 4.290
b2 – −0.4151 – −0.7004
SD,
All data 8.0% 5.8% 19.3% 9.3%
SD p≤200MPa 8.2% 4.8% 13.8% 5.4%
α*(T = 100 °C) (GPa−1) 13.1 12.5 17.0 17.8
α* (T=100degC ) From data 12.2 16.9

The improvement in the representation of the fragility can be seen in Figure 1 where the pressure Stickel function,16 S (p )= [∂ln (μ )/∂p ]-1/2, is plotted for the measured data and for the two Yasutomi versions. The inflection occurs at p=pnfl where ∂2 (lnμ )/∂p2=0, that is, at the maximum of the Stickel plot. The measured data at three temperatures show inflections at approximately 0.75, 0.95 and 1.05 GPa, as does the improved model, whereas the original Yasutomi does not. Therefore, the improved model is more appropriate for traction analysis when the Hertz pressure exceeds the inflection pressure. It can also be seen from Figure 1, where S (p ) of either model fails to reproduce the rapid decrease in the measured values, that a regression analysis will not necessarily reproduce the pressure fragility unless data are collected at pressures much greater than the infection pressure where S decreases linearly16 with p. Figure 1.
Stickel plot showing the improved representation of fragility in squalane by F' (p ) over F (p ).

The improved model also shows better agreement with measurements at lower pressures in Figure 1. In fact, the new model for p≤200 MPa improves the standard deviation from 8.2% to 4.8%, indicating that it may be more precise for determining the pressure–viscosity coefficient, α*=1/∫0 ∞μ (p=0 )dp/μ (p ).

A second example comes from the commercial traction fluid used in the Nissan CVT transmission.10 Data to 140 °C are from Bair.17 The parameters are listed in Table 1. The parameters for the original model, using F (p ), are from Bair and Kottke11 and the parameters for the improved model, using F' (p ), are newly regressed. The viscosities at 140 °C are plotted in Figure 2 where it can be seen that the new formulation for the relative free volume expansivity improves the representation of viscosity above a pressure of 800 MPa. In fact, the old model has two inflections in Figure 2, one at 0.08 GPa and another at 0.78 GPa. The data, of course, do not indicate a second inflection and the new model gives a single inflection at 0.14 GPa, consistent with the data. Figure 2.
The viscosity of the commercial traction fluid, measured and predicted from the original and from the improved models with an insert in the high pressure region.

A third illustration is reported in Table 2. It concerns automotive and industrial lubricants: HMB is a hydro-cracked mineral base oil, PGB is a polyalkylene glycol base oil, HMB P1 is composed of HMB + 1.2% w/w PMA polymer, HMB P2 means HMB + 1.2% w/w OCP + PISH polymers, and NT9 represents a new batch of the formulated Shell T9 used in Habchi et al.3 Measurements were made to maximum pressure of 800 MPa. For the examples of Table 2, Tg0 values were determined from a wider range of temperature, including very low temperatures, using a different viscometer at atmospheric pressure. The isobaric form of the Williams–Landel–Ferry equation, equation (1) with F=1,17 was used to find Tg0 from these data before the other parameters were regressed. For the five complementary fluids presented in Table 2, a rather significant improvement is obtained that leads to a more accurate prediction of the low pressure behavior of these lubricants. This is illustrated in Figure 3 for HMB P2 at 100 °C, where an insert at low pressure (p < 0.2 GPa) shows the improved accuracy afforded by the modification within a pressure range of critical importance for determining α*, a parameter for predicting film thickness in Newtonian EHL. Figure 3.
The viscosity of an automotive lubricant at 100 °C with an insert in the low pressure region (p ≤ 150 MPa).
Table 2.

SD, All data 5.1% 2.6% 4.9% 4.2% 7.9% 5.4% 6.8% 4.8% 6.8% 4.9%
SD p≤200MPa 5.1% 3.1% 5.2% 4.2% 7.5% 5.2% 6.8% 4.3% 5.5% 4.3%

For the examples of Table 2, the measured viscosity data do not include the inflection at p=pnfl except for NT9. For example, at 65 °C, the inflection is predicted from the improved correlation, for the other four liquids, to occur at pressures greater than 1.6 GPa, which greatly exceeds the pressures of the experimental measurements. However, it would be unusual for a liquid lubricant at this temperature to have such a high inflection pressure. For NT9 at 65 °C, pnfl=0.25GPa, for the commercial traction fluid at 65 °C, pnfl=-0.09GPa and for squalane at 65 °C, pnfl=1.03GPa, as examples. The problem arises from the difficulty in predicting the inflection from viscosities measured at lower pressures. The Yasutomi correlation can reproduce the inflection; however, if the inflection is not present in the measurements then some of the parameters are not uniquely determined by the data.

The original Yasutomi correlation has been shown18 to accurately represent the dependence of the glass transition temperature on pressure from viscosity data. The new formulation alters this representation. It remains to be seen whether this alteration will reduce the accuracy of the glass temperature.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The original Yasutomi correlation suffers from the appearance of a zero in the function describing the pressure dependence of the relative free volume thermal expansivity. When the original correlation is employed, a liquid with a high inflection pressure lacks the inflection in the predicted pressure–viscosity behavior and a liquid with a low inflection pressure is predicted to have two inflections. A new function removes these concerns and provides improved precision without the need for an equation of state. The improved function gives a more faithful representation of viscosity at even low pressures.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Bair was supported by the Center for Compact and Efficient Fluid Power, a National Science Foundation Engineering Research Center funded under cooperative agreement number EEC-0540834.

low-shear viscosity at the glass transition
